bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry, April 10 and 11,1729

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant Micajah Perry, April 10, 1729, concerning and defending his administration of the John Lloyd estates. In a brief post script dictated the next day, Carter notes that he has found some accounts for the Lloyd estate for 1711 and 1712 and is enclosing copies (not present).

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Micajah Perry, April 10 and 11,1729

opener.dateline:
Rappahannock, [Lancaster County, Virginia]
Apl. 10th: —1729
Alderman Perry

div1.p:
In one of yor. Letters you desire me to Send you
Accots. of the Disbursemts. upon the LLs Estate from Yr. 1711 to 1718
this is a very hard task and it is Impossible for me at this distance of
time to produce all the Vouchers to them Accots: You cannot Expect
wee are as regular in our books as you Merchts. are whose business
it is to transact Affairs for other men had yor. Grandfather & Father
made any Exceptions to any Articles in them Accots: it was then in
my Power to have Justifyed them in every Punctilio, but Seeing
they have Past and I have had Credit for them so long ago I cant
think it my business at this time of day to be Concernd about them
however that I may give you all the light in my Power I now Trans=
mit you all these Copys of these Accots: you desire even down to 1721 as I find them in my books
Together with what Vouchers I have, Colonel Tayloe's Tobbo: Accot. for
the Year 1713 I Send you but his Accot. for the Year 1712 for 9060 pounds Tobbo: I can find
nothing of for 960 pounds and I am very well Satisfyed there is no
footstep of it to be found with him. You have here a Tobbo: Accot. for the Yr.
1715 where you will find the Debts that Year paid out of the Crops, You
are pleased to tell me they are very Clamerous against these Accots.
and Tax me of Several Indirect Practices I can only answer they are
under very wrong Informations I can very well Justifye my Integrity
and Justice in this whole Affair and that I do not deserve those Severa[l]
Censures they are Pleased to Vent against me, The Persons I have employ'd
more Immedately in the Care of this estate are Colonel Tayloe, Capt Tubervile
and Mr. Richard Meeks all Still living to be Appealed to, to run its Part=
[i]culars to answer every malitious little Storey that ma[y] Perhaps have bin
hatched by Some over Officious Persons, would be En[. . .] I wear a
higher Character in yor. Esteem and the Esteem [...]
Then to think me capable of mean Pittfull Arts and frauds for a
little gain to my Self, I thank God from the interest of my money I cant
charge my Self with no Such thing.

I have so often inculcated to you the meanest of the Plans:
how much the Lands there were were overstockd with Slaves, how Im=
possible it was to make tolerable Crops with them and how absolutely
necessary it was to find more Lands for the better half of these Slaves &ca:
that I Shall not repeat any of these things but refer you to abundance
of former Letters which are full of this Subject, I Shall observe one
thing to you which I think proper for yr. Information when I Entred
upon this Estate Qt. rents was paid for 4,000 and odd Acs: of Land, the
mistake I was under for Sometime but when I came to be better Acq=
uainted with the Several Tracts I could find but 2330 Acs: of which Mr.
Carys Survey being a much Elder Grant took away between 4 & 500 Acs:
which has reduced the Land to 1900 & odd Acs: When this Estate was deliverd into
my hands the hous's upon the Sevl. Plantations
were so gon to decay and out of repair that
wee were forced to make all new buildings & wee also then Seated two new
Plantations out of the Woods this made the Charge run high for the first Years, but the
Crops then answerd very well while the Lands were fresh

Upon Consideration of the great trouble I have bin at
thro this whole affair in Yor. Grandfather Fathers and yor. own time
which you cannot but be very Sensible of in a great measure your Self
I hope according to yours and their promises you will take care upon
the passing yor. Accots. that I am allowd a Suitable Salary I have Said
So much of this to all of you already and make Such Continual Claim
that this seems hardly necessary to you Now I am
div1.closer:
Sir—
Yor. most humble Servt:—
Since writeing the above I have accidentally fallen on Some
rough Accots. between Colonel Tayloe & I which will Serve for Vouchers for the
Year 1712 Also a mixt Accot. for 1711 between him and I in which is Con-
taind [...] my Paying to him the Accot. of Loyds Estate
and will give Some light into the Charges of 1711. Copys of these I also
Enclose, And now you have all the light that I can give you and indeed
more then I Expected to be able to furnish, You may please to observe for
the first Year or two before you Sent in Supplys for the familys wee were forced
to buy goods in the Country as we could get them I am
Sir—
Yor. most humble Servt.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond. Carter addresses Perry as "Alderman" because Perry had been elected an alderman of London in February 1728. (Price. Perry of London. . . . p. 7.)

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.

[1] John Tayloe (1687-1747) of Mt. Airy, Richmond County, who served as justice, burgess, colonel of militia, and as a member of the Council after 1732. (Ryland. Richmond County Virginia. . . . pp. 115-16.)
